head.headtext: Pleas, plea discussions, and related statements

para.paratext: In general, pleas of guilty that are later withdrawn, nolo contendere pleas, and all statements made during plea negotiations or during proceedings for the two aforementioned pleas are not admissible against the criminal defendant who made the plea or participated in the negotiations.[1] However, these items are admissible in any proceeding wherein another statement made in the course of the same plea or plea discussions has been introduced and the statement ought in fairness be considered contemporaneously with it or in a criminal proceeding for perjury or false statement if the statement was made by the accused under oath, on the record, and in the presence of counsel or after the accused voluntarily waived his right to counsel.[2]

In Flading v. State,[3] the court considered relevant stipulations at an ALS hearing that a driver would plead guilty to a DUI in exchange for the return of his driver's license, and allowed the stipulation to be entered into evidence at trial for the underlying DUI. The court reasoned that, under the new Evidence Code, the relevance standard is a “low standard” and the defendant's stipulation, although not dispositive, was certainly relevant to the DUI charge.

Flading v. State, 327 Ga. App. 346, 759 S.E.2d 67 (2014). The Court of Appeals again considered the issue, and held such stipulations admissible in Adams v. State, 344 Ga. App. 159, 809 S.E.2d 87 (2017).
